awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Quantum many-body physics beyond the Boltzmann paradigm: prethermalization, many-body localization, and their applications
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research and the Division of Physics contribute funds to this CAREER award, which supports theoretical research and education on the dynamics of quantum systems made up from many interacting particles. 

The project explores quantum systems that take anomalously long to approach thermal equilibrium (or, in some extreme cases, never approach equilibrium). The approach to equilibrium involves a system "forgetting" information about its initial state. For example, if a gas is initially put in the left side of a tube, and then is allowed to spread throughout the tube, it eventually forgets which side it started out in. This apparent "forgetting" is at odds with the laws of quantum mechanics, which in fact conserve information; it is believed that information about the initial state is never truly forgotten, but is stored in complicated, experimentally inaccessible correlations. How information migrates from measurable to hidden correlations is in general not understood. 

This project approaches the general question from the perspective of states of matter related to glasses, in which "forgetting" is extremely slow. In the intermediate regimes, some sectors of the system are in equilibrium, whereas others are far from it. New theoretical methods that generalize conventional statistical mechanics are required to characterize these intermediate regimes. Developing such methods and using them to identify distinctive features of these intermediate regimes are primary objectives of this project. The other major focus of this project is to use slowly equilibrating systems for novel quantum applications, including heat engines, quantum memories, and sensors. Since equilibration corresponds to the forgetting or hiding of information, systems that are slow to equilibrate retain information for very long times; this observation underlies the various applications that will be explored in this project. 

This project will take place at the College of Staten Island, which has a diverse student body including large proportions of first-generation college students, underrepresented minorities, and recent immigrants. Educational activities will include curricular development to make physics relevant for this wide range of students, including the reorientation of standard courses to emphasize general-purpose computational methods, which are useful in a wide range of professions, as well as development of new courses on complex systems. Outreach to the broader community will involve developing a mini museum that will illustrate universal phenomena in everyday life through simple interactive exhibits.  


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research and the Division of Physics contribute funds to this CAREER award, which supports theoretical research and education on the properties of interacting quantum systems that approach thermal equilibrium anomalously slowly: i.e., systems for which the thermalization timescale is much longer than other intrinsic timescales. These include isolated systems that are nearly integrable or nearly many-body localized, as well as related open systems. The main goals of this project are threefold: to develop computational methods suited to slowly thermalizing systems, to characterize distinctively non-thermal features of distribution functions in such systems, and to apply these distinctive features to quantum technologies. 

The first main goal is to develop methods to describe the dynamics of slowly thermalizing systems. Existing approaches are typically limited to short times and/or small systems, owing to the growth of entanglement. This project will develop methods tailored to the intermediate and late-time behavior of slowly thermalizing systems. Specifically, field theories of the prethermalized regime, as well as mean-field and renormalization-group techniques that leverage the separation of timescales between interactions and thermalization to describe the emergence of thermal behavior. These methods will be applied to experiments involving ultracold atomic systems that are nearly integrable (one-dimensional dipolar gases) or many-body localized. The second main goal is to characterize the probability distributions of physical observables in slowly thermalizing systems, focusing on many-body localization. Such distributions are expected to be fat-tailed; this project will characterize these tails, and their implications for observables such as the nonlinear response. The third main goal is to explore applications of non-thermalizing systems (again, focusing on the many-body localized case) for quantum information science, quantum metrology, and quantum thermodynamics. 

This project will take place at the College of Staten Island, which has a diverse student body including large proportions of first-generation college students, underrepresented minorities, and recent immigrants. Educational activities will include curricular development to make physics relevant for this wide range of students, including the reorientation of standard courses to emphasize general-purpose computational methods, which are useful in a wide range of professions, as well as development of new courses on complex systems. Outreach to the broader community will involve developing a mini museum that will illustrate universal phenomena in everyday life through simple interactive exhibits.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to clarify how our normal intuitions about temperature, thermal equilibrium, and similar concepts emerge?or, in some cases, fail to emerge?from the quantum mechanics of many interacting particles. It led to many foundational discoveries. 

First, this project transformed our understanding of the dynamics of one-dimensional, and approximately one-dimensional, magnetic systems, elucidating how such systems can undergo phase transitions in their dynamical behavior even when their thermal equilibrium states do not sense these phase transitions, and developing methods to understand these phase transitions theoretically and to realize them experimentally. This project settled several open questions in this area, some of which had been open for over a decade. Key among these results were: the explanation of superdiffusion in the Heisenberg and Hubbard models, the prediction of anomalous local relaxation as well as anomalous full counting statistics in spin systems with anisotropic interactions, and the realization that the conductivity of such spin chains could change anomalously (in fact, discontinuously) under certain infinitesimal changes to the dynamical rules. These results, and the technical achievements in the field of ?generalized hydrodynamics? on which they were built, led to many high-profile publications as well as the stimulation of new experimental efforts in many groups worldwide.

Second, this project made key contributions to the theory of how measurements affect quantum many-body states. The process of measurement plays a basic part in quantum mechanics, since each measurement ?collapses? the quantum state that it probes. How continuously measuring a many-body system affects its properties used to be an unexplored question; in the past four years, many surprising consequences of measurement were discovered, in significant part because of this project. Key among these was the finding that measurements induce phase transitions in the structure of quantum entanglement in systems of many interacting particles. The significant achievements of this project include theories of measurement-induced entanglement phase transitions in a variety of settings (including the cases of models where the dynamics is due exclusively to measurements, and those in which one looks at the system conditional on a particular set of measurement outcomes), the study of the critical properties of such transitions, and the interpretation of measurement-induced transitions as ?learnability? transitions in the amount of information an eavesdropper can learn from continuously measuring the output of a quantum system. A closely related recent advance was to develop a family of recipes for generating systems with high levels of quantum entanglement by collecting the quantum information radiated from an open quantum system.

In addition to these two major thrusts, this project supported pioneering work on a variety of topics, including: pioneering the application of random matrix theory to open quantum systems, the creation and exploration of far-from-equilibrium long-lived "quantum scar" states of ultracold gases, a framework for interpreting experiments on the response of materials driven by strong electric fields, and the development of the first theoretical tools for studying the onset of chaos in quantum systems close to special ?integrable? limits (i.e., limits in which interactions are present but do not lead to chaos). Many of these results were achieved in collaboration with experimental groups. 

In conjunction with these research achievements, the project led to several advances in physics education. First, the PI developed a ?mathematical methods? curriculum for graduate students focused on themes that are useful for present-day research, e.g., the basic mathematics behind machine learning and tensor networks. Second, the PI developed new courses at the undergraduate and graduate levels on quantum information and quantum computing, to meet student demand for both rapidly developing topics. Unlike many classic treatments of this topic (developed 10-15 years ago), these courses focus on the ideas and techniques that are most related to recent and prospective developments in the field, focusing on questions such as error correction and verification rather than on algorithms. Third, the PI (in collaboration with colleagues at CUNY) developed an online educational resource on ?physics for everyone.? This resource, which continues to be updated, includes lectures and demos introducing many advanced concepts in physics using phenomena from the everyday world, such as the splashing of droplets of water and the shapes of coffee stains.


Last Modified: 09/04/2023
Modified by: Sarang Gopalakrishnan

Images (1 of )
  • Interpretation of the measurement-induced phase transition for systems with conserved charge as a transition in whether an adversary given the outcomes of local charge measurements taking place during the time evolution can infer the total charge of the system.
    Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 200602 (2022)
    Copyrighted
    Sarang Gopalakrishnan
    interpretation of measurement-induced transitions as learnability transitions
  • When a lump of magnetization is added to an anisotropic spin chain, it splits into a fast part and a slow part, which propagate at very different rates. The fast part moves out ballistically while the slow part spreads with an anomalous exponent.
    PNAS 116, 16250 (2019)
    Copyrighted
    Sarang Gopalakrishnan
    spreading of magnetization in anisotropic spin chains
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project aimed to clarify how our normal intuitions about temperature, thermal equilibrium, and similar concepts emerge?or, in some cases, fail to emerge?from the quantum mechanics of many interacting particles. It led to many foundational discoveries. 
First, this project transformed our understanding of the dynamics of one-dimensional, and approximately one-dimensional, magnetic systems, elucidating how such systems can undergo phase transitions in their dynamical behavior even when their thermal equilibrium states do not sense these phase transitions, and developing methods to understand these phase transitions theoretically and to realize them experimentally. Many of these results were achieved in collaboration with experimental groups. 
In conjunction with these research achievements, the project led to several advances in physics education. First, the PI developed a ?mathematical methods? curriculum for graduate students focused on themes that are useful for present-day research, e.g., the basic mathematics behind machine learning and tensor networks. Second, the PI developed new courses at the undergraduate and graduate levels on quantum information and quantum computing, to meet student demand for both rapidly developing topics. Third, the PI (in collaboration with colleagues at CUNY) developed an online educational resource on ?physics for everyone.? This resource, which continues to be updated, includes lectures and demos introducing many advanced concepts in physics using phenomena from the everyday world, such as the splashing of droplets of water and the shapes of coffee stains.
